body:
### Problem

I'm not aware of a simple way to update the settings of an already running LSP server.

### Expected behavior

Sending a `workspace/didChangeConfiguration` notification prompts the server to pull the new workspace configuration from the client. The `settings` field is basically [legacy](https://github.com/microsoft/language-server-protocol/issues/676), but still needs to be considered for some edge cases. While `rust_analyzer` completely ignores the field, it's still required to be present so the notification parameters get parsed without any errors. `tinymist` is even more tricky, since it checks if the `settings` field is a JSON object and if so uses it directly without the additional server request. I guess this isn't spec compliant behavior, but it might be worth considering still sending the full settings value in the notification to support legacy behavior.
Regarding the `workspace/configuration` handler, I think no changes are necessary, apart from updating `settings` of the active clients.

This would allow reconfiguring an already running server, without the need for a full restart.

I currently have the following code snippet, which lets me change the server settings of `rust_analyzer`:
```lua
    for _, client in ipairs(vim.lsp.get_clients({ name = "rust_analyzer" })) do
        -- Update the settings on the active client.
        client.settings = vim.lsp.config.rust_analyzer.settings
        -- Send a notification with empty settings, rust_analyzer pulls the
        -- configuration using a `workspace/configuration` request.
        client:notify("workspace/didChangeConfiguration", { settings = {} })
    end
```

It would be great if this notification and the settings update would be done automatically if the server updated using `vim.lsp.config` has an active client.
title: Send LSP `workspace/didChangeConfiguration` notification when reconfiguring `vim.lsp.config`
